qas.question: Where is antimatter found naturally in large quantities?
What is an example of an antiparticle?
Large quantities of what can be created for testing?

context: Antimatter is not found naturally on <b0_0>Earth<b0_0/>, except very briefly and in vanishingly small quantities (as the result of radioactive decay, lightning or cosmic rays). This is because antimatter that came to exist on Earth outside the confines of <b2_0>a suitable physics laboratory<b2_0/> would almost instantly meet the <b1_0>ordinary matter<b1_0/> that Earth is made of, and be annihilated. <b4_0>Antiparticles and some stable antimatter<b4_0/> (such as <b3_0>antihydrogen<b3_0/>) can be made in tiny amounts, but not in enough quantity to do more than test a few of its theoretical properties.
